user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_check_response_header_token_ci:
```c
bool
MHD_check_response_header_token_ci (const struct MHD_Response *response,
                                    const char *key,
                                    size_t key_len,
                                    const char *token,
                                    size_t token_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if ( (NULL == key) ||
       ('\0' == key[0]) ||
       (NULL == token) ||
       ('\0' == token[0]) )
    return false;

  /* Token must not contain binary zero! */
  mhd_assert (strlen (token) == token_len);

  for (pos = response->first_header;
       NULL != pos;
       pos = pos->next)
  {
    if ( (pos->kind == MHD_HEADER_KIND) &&
         (key_len == pos->header_size) &&
         MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header,
                                        key,
                                        key_len) &&
         MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (pos->value,
                                      token,
                                      token_len) )
      return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is assigned to or otherwise modified in this function. Details:
- response: only read (accessed as response->first_header); there is no assignment to response itself and no pointer arithmetic changing the parameter.
- key and token: only dereferenced/read (NULL checks, key[0], token[0]) and passed to other functions; the pointer variables themselves are not reassigned or incremented.
- key_len and token_len: only read for comparisons and passed to helper functions; not modified.
- The loop variable pos is a local pointer and is updated (pos = pos->next), not any of the function parameters.
- The mhd_assert(strlen(token) == token_len) call reads the object pointed to by token but does not modify the token parameter itself.

Note: calls to MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ and MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ pass pointer parameters by value; whether those called functions modify the pointed-to objects is outside this function and (per MISRA Rule 17.8) modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted. There are no assignments to the parameter variables themselves in this code, so no fragments require further investigation for Rule 17.8.
